ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Fowler Packing Co. recognizes the companys responsibility in ensuring the safety of the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at the Fowler Packing Co. facility in Fresno, California.

Fowler Packing Co. senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities.  Management administers the safety and environmental policies and programs. These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communication, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety training, Emergency Action Plan, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

Fowler Packing personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system. In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, and Cold Storage Manager and/or their supervisor.  Outside emergency responding agencies are also notified as appropriate, which is detailed in the Emergency Action Plan policy.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Fowler Packing facility is located at 8570 S. Cedar Avenue in Fresno, California.  The facility is located approximately 4.9 miles west of Highway 99 and 1.9 miles east of Highway 41. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of farmland and residential areas.

The facilitys Plant 1 and 2 ammonia refrigeration systems maintain a maximum of 21,000 and 28,000 pounds respectively.  The refrigeration systems, consisting of pipin

g, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the packing and cold storage of local agricultural products.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the system are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration systems are closed-loop systems without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks / unanticipated ammonia odors are noted and repaired immediately.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal-OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Section 5189 of Title 8, CCR) and the EPA Risk Management Program.  This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity of either PSM or RMP rules.

The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:

  --  Process Safety Information includes the compilation of the technical design details of each refrigeration system, including manufacturer specifications, piping diagrams, safety system design, etc.  PSI is made available to all applicable employees upon hire and is accessible at all times.
  --  Process Hazard Analysis studies are completed every five years by qualified personnel using techniques approved under the PSM standard to identify and mitigate the risks associated with the design and operations of each of the regulated processes (ammonia refrigeration systems).
  --  Operating Procedu

res are prepared for all ammonia refrigeration equipment, and are used for training and guiding the work of refrigeration operators and mechanics.
  --  Training is provided to all employees upon hire that includes ammonia hazard awareness, ammonia refrigeration basics and operations with an emphasis on safety.  Refresher training is also provided at least every three years.
  --  Contractors that work on or near ammonia refrigeration equipment are vetted to ensure contractor employees are properly qualified and trained before coming onsite.  Fowler Packing Co. also provides training regarding the facilitys safe work practices.
  --  The Management of Change policy requires facility personnel to evaluate proposed changes to the ammonia systems to ensure that new hazards are not introduced, and that the various PSM / RMP elements are kept current based on changes.
  --  Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are conducted to ensure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied prior to starting new or modified equipment.
  --  The Mechanical Integrity policy details the prescribed inspections, testing, and maintenance activities that are conducted on all ammonia refrigeration system equipment, as well as some auxiliary systems.  This includes preventative maintenance + inspections conducted by Fowler Packing Co. personnel as well as by outside refrigeration contractors.
  --  A Hot Work Permit policy assures that hot work conducted around ammonia refrigeration equipment and/or piping is done safely and properly.
Incident Investigations are conducted for unanticipated ammonia issues, and actions are recommended as appropriate to avoid similar situations from occurring again as part of a continuous improvement effort.
  --  Routine Compliance Audits are conducted to assure that the PSM / RMP elements are developed in accordance with the regulations as well as industry standards and best practices.  Recommendations can be made to modify the policies and/or record keeping

practices.

This systematic approach to process safety involves employees and strives for continuing improvements in overall safety. The training, qualifications, and safety awareness of the operations, maintenance, and management personnel are a key element in reducing and mitigating risks associated with handling ammonia.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Fowler Packing Co.  It is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220), as well as EPAs Emergency Response Plan.

Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency response procedures and the evacuation plan.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, maintenance personnel, and/or their supervisor.  Maintenance personnel will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  All employees evacuate to the assembly areas.  Notifications of response agencies as well the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is also detailed the Emergency Response policy.  The Fowler Packing Co. facility also has an established relationship with the local Fire Department and County Hazardous Materials Response Team who may be called in to assist depending on the scope of an emergency situation.

The Emergency Plan policy contains procedures detailing how the facility will react to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This policy has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies.

The facilitys Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --

Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training

Evacuation drills are also organized and conducted annually to supplement the training received by all employees at the facility.  As facility management strives to improve safety at the facility, evaluations are documented with suggested improvements, and other observations from the drills.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPAs RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

  --  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
  --  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facilitys accident history revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases over the past five years (July 2019  July 2024) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the California state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Fowler Packing Co. has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Fowler Packing Co., with support from contractors and consultants entrenched in the ammonia refrigeration industry, strives to ensure a safe working environment at the facility for all employees, guests, and visitors.  The facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

  --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.
  --  Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training classes to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.
  --  Conducting routine RMP / PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by facility personnel, refrigeration contractors, or consultants are discussed and addressed.
  --  Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facilitys efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.
